attributes.title: Stock Verification
attributes.description:
The audit findings were as seen below:

  • Bread stock had a variance of +46 pieces
  • Polybags had -221
  • Yeast -1.02 sachets
  • White flour had -0.88 kgs
  • Utto had +0.77 kgs.
  • Crates had Nil variation.

Below is a detailed summary of the audit findings:
attributes.recommendation: Branch management to ensure proper recording of both raw materials and finished product  and regular stock counts is done to minimise the variations.
attributes.effect:
The variations noted however minimal implies that the branch should maintain and strengthen the existing controls.

Nil variation in crates implies crates movement controls are working effectively.

value: We will try to reduce variations by insisting of regular shiftwise stock counts.
We will try to reduce variations by insisting of regular shiftwise stock counts.

In the prior audit report dated 26/06/2025,the following were noted:

  •  Bread stock showed a Surplus of + 36.5 Loaves,
  • White flour had a variance of -1.15Kgs
  •   Yeast had 1 sachet.
  • Packing material had a short fall of -157 pieces,
  • Utto had a variance of -0.77 units while other stock items had a minimal Variation.
  • Crates had nil variation.
Current
A physical stock count of raw materials and finished product was done on 27/06/2025.
Variations were minimal however stock movement controls should be enhanced to ensure nil variance.
Operations/Production Department

The aim of this exercise was to check if stock movement controls in place was working effectively.

To check if physical stock count was in agreement with balances in SAP.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart analysis
attributes.description:
The analysis showed the following:

  • Average yield was at 191.07
    650  remixes were noted for the period under review.
  • Average daily production was at 40.86  bags for a period of 35 days which represents 75.66% production capacity utilization hence there is still room for improvement.
  • Utto Consumption to bags was 1:1.

Detailed analysis as seen below:
attributes.recommendation:
Branch management to put efforts to increase sales to ensure Branch production capacity is achieved.

Branch management to report promptly whenever there are breakdowns to reduce remixes that affect bread quality.
attributes.effect:
Remixes noted reduces quality of bread.

Production capacity not achieved implies that the branch capacity was underutilized.

value:
Remixes were as a result of Oven MBN 141 breakdowns but the issue was rectified.
Yield is okey we will continue with the same trend.
Production capacity not attained was a result of low sales,hence we cut production,we also rely on branch transfers.
Utto consumption okey we will continue with the same trend.

Remixes were as a result of Oven MBN 141 breakdowns but the issue was rectified.
Yield is okey we will continue with the same trend.
Production capacity not attained was a result of low sales,hence we cut production,we also rely on branch transfers.
Utto consumption okey we will continue with the same trend.

In the prior audit report the following were noted:

  • Utto consumption to bags was 100%
  • Average yield was at 191.06 Loaves per Bag.
  • Average production was at 46.6 bags which represented 86.30%  production capacity achievement
  • There were remixes however it was noted remixes were being done but they were not being recorded in the chart.
Current
Analysis of both mixing chart and mixing chart summary was done for a period of 35 days from 24th May  2025 to 27rd June 2025 .

Raw materials consumption was as per the set BOM.

Branch production capacity was underutilized.
Operations/Production Department

To determine if Branch production capacity was being fully utilized.

To determine if Raw material consumption was being done as per the set branch BOM.

attributes.title: Damages analysis.
attributes.description:
It was noted that production damages was at 0.206 % of total production which was above the limit 0f 0.20% by 0.006 % with a cost implication of Kshs.860.87 while t Market damages were  at 0.43 % which was within the allowable limit.

Below is a detailed summary of the audit findings:

Production damages.

N/B The above analysis is exclusive of 90 Pieces of Oven damage.

Market Damages

Damages sent to ingredient department.

Damages sent to ingredient department were less by 7.72 Kgs as seen below:
attributes.recommendation:
Branch should ensure bread of good quality is produced to reduce production damages.

Proper recording of all damages should be done to ensure expected damages in reconciliation with those sent to ingredient department are in agreement with physically available damages.
attributes.effect:
Minimal variations noted implies that the branch was producing bread of good quality.

Less damages sent to ingredient department implies  improper recording of damages.

value:
Proper follow up on production procedures will be done to avoid high % of damages.

Market damages threshold to be maintained.

To be rectified to  avoid repetition of the same.

Proper follow up on production procedures will be done to avoid high % of damages.

Market damages threshold to be maintained.

To be rectified to  avoid repetition of the same.
In the prior audit dated 26/05/2025,it was noted that production damages were at 0.21% of total production while market damages were at 0.37% which were within the allowable limits.
Current
Damages analysis was done for a period of 35 days from 24th May 2025-27th  June 2025 for  market, production related damages and damages sent to ingredient department.

Production damages exceeded the allowable limits by 0.06%

Market damages were within the allowable limits.

Damages sent to ingredient were less by 7.72kgs which was minimal.
Operations/Production Department

To determine if damages were within the allowable limits of 0.2% for production related damages and 0.5% of total sales for market damages.

To determine if all reported damages were all accounted for by sending to ingredient department.

attributes.title: Bread weights.
attributes.description: Bread weight check was as seen below:
attributes.recommendation:
Branch to ensure correct production procedures are followed to reduces  lapses that result in Underweights.

Standard dough weight to be strictly adhered to.
attributes.effect:
Distributing underweight products to the market can result in substantial financial losses and reputational harm, especially if regulatory agencies or weight enforcement authorities conduct inspections.

Providing underweight bread may also lead to decreased sales and a loss of market share, as dissatisfied customers are likely to switch to competitors who offer properly weighted products

value: Underweights were as a result of new slicer which didn't follow the correct cooling time  to but proper coaching will be iniated to ensure they are following the correct procedures to reduce cases of underweights.
We will be cheking on this to avoid the underweight.

In the prior audit dated 26/05/2025,underweights were as seen below:

  • 400Gg ctw had 38%
  • 400 BT had 24%
  • 600 BT had 48%
  • 800 BT/CTW had 21%
Current

A weight check on the bread produced and packed at the branch was done on 26/05/2025

to ensure that the bread sent to the market complied with the KEBS standard weights of

200g, 400g, 600g, and 800g.
Underweights were noted across all sampled varieties weighed as described above.
Operations/Production Department

To ensure that the bread sent to the market complied with the KEBS standard weights of

200g, 400g, 600g, and 800g.

To determine if standard dough weight was being adhered to.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description: It was noted that production efficiency stood at 3.99 ,excess workers hired were 40  with a cost implication of Kshs.43,464.00 as shown below:
attributes.recommendation: Allocation of workers to be done as per the shift targets to avoid extra costs incured for hiring excess workers.
attributes.effect: Production efficiency below the set KPI implies that production workers were not fully utilized 40 extra workers were hired with an extra cost of KES 43,464

value: Production efficiency was affected by new employees and shift cuts but we shall ensure proper allocation of workers.
Production efficiency was affected by new employees and shift cuts but we shall ensure proper allocation of workers.
In the prior audit dated 26/05/2025,it was noted that production efficiency stood at 4.144
Current
Production efficiency was done for a period of 35 days from 24th May 2025-27 June 2025.
Production workers not fully utilized.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if branch production workers were being fully utilized by attaining their KPI of 4.3 bags per production worker.

attributes.title: Packing efficiency.
attributes.description: It was noted that packing efficiency stood at 94.73 crates per packer ,4 extra workers were hired with a cost implication of Kshs.3,648 as seen below:
attributes.recommendation: Allocation of packers to be done as per prior shift loaves produced.
attributes.effect: Packers are not fully utilized,4 extra workers were hired with a cost implication of Kshs.3648

value: We shall allocate packers based on prior shift loaves produced.
We shall allocate packers based on prior shift loaves produced.
In the prior audit it was noted that packing efficiency was at 89.99 crates per packer.
Current
Packing efficiency was done for a period of 35 days from 24th May 2025-27th June 2025.
Packers  did not attain their KPI.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if packers were achieving their KPI of 97 crates per packer.

attributes.title: Vehicles fuel consumption
attributes.description: It was noted that fuel consumption was within the standard rates however  KBV 977 For Imara route saved 20 litres fuel, consumption rate to be checked as seen below:
attributes.recommendation: Standard consumption rate for KBV 977 V to be reviewed since its saving significant fuel.

value: Fuel allocation to be maintained and standard conumption for KBV 977 V to be reviewed by transport department.
Noted will check on it.
In the prior audit report dated 26/05/2025,it was noted that fuel consumption was within the standard rate.
Current
Vehicles fuel consumption was done for a period of 27 days from 1st June 2025-27th June 2025.
Fuel consumption within range to be maintained.
Operations/Production Department
To check if fuel consumption was well managed.

attributes.title: Minishop
attributes.description: A spot check on minishop showed a variance of Kshs.119.85 which was attributed as transaction as seen below:

value: Mini shop controls to be maintained.
Noted.
In the prior audit mini shop spot check had nil variation.
Current
A Spot check on mini shop was done on 27th June 2025.
Mini shop controls working effectively.
Operations/Production Department

To determine if all bread loaded was well accounted for and sales agreed with Mpesa Till

balances.

attributes.title: Cash verification.
attributes.description: Cash count showed  variation was noted as seen below:
attributes.effect: Nil variations implies  that cash handling procedures are working effectively.

value: Same trend to be maintained.
Noted.
In the prior audit it was noted that cash had nil variation however the was a pending IOU of Kshs 5,000 that was past the 3 day clearance policy.
Current
A spot check on cash office was done on 27/06/2025.
Cash controls operating effectively.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if Physical cash was tallying with the balances as per cashflow and to determine if all IOUS were within the 3 day clearance policy.

attributes.title: Generator fuel consumption
attributes.description: Generator Fuel consumption for the month of June  was within the range, However it was noted that the branch had fuel that were Purchased in excess as seen below:
attributes.effect: Fuel well managed, however fuel purchase in bulk should be avoided.

value: Excess fuel was purchased due low tank capacity .
Excess fuel was purchased due low tank capacity we have to keep fuel during the emergency
N/A
Current
Generator fuel consumption was done for the period of 27 days from 1st June 2025-27th June 2025.
Fuel well managed, however fuel purchase in bulk should be avoided.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Debtors analysis.
attributes.description:
A total of 272,655  debtors were noted exclusive of advance payments  which most were those of instituitions ,with 2 not active customers totalling to 14,293,and one dormant customer with a balance of 1,335.

Below is the detailed summary of the audit findings:
attributes.recommendation: Sales rep to follow up on the pending balances to be cleared.
attributes.effect:
Significant debtors’ balances pose a risk of  non-payment to the company and a follow-up

for clearance should be enhanced. Dormant customers inflate receivable balances.

value: This is noted  for follow up to be done with the sales rep to ensure balances are cleared.
We will follow up to be done with the sales rep to ensure balances are cleared.

In the previous audit report dated 26th May 2025,A total of KES 354,394.46 debtors were noted exclusive of Advance payments which most were those of institutions except a few customers who were transferred to Mini shop kware with a balances of KES 33,552.Two dormant accounts were also noted with balances of KES.10,177
Current
Analysis of debtors balances as of 27/06/2025.
Pending balances to be followed up for clearance.
Sales Department
To determine if there were any instances of bad debtors and to determine the magnitude of debtors balance.
